body:
Several times I've run into a situation where I open a flutter project/module in a copy of IntelliJ that has the Dart plugin installed but not the Flutter plugin. IntelliJ displays an error message about not understanding the module type.

I think we want the Flutter modules to be a slightly different flavor of Dart modules, not an entirely different module type. So, the Dart plugin could work with Flutter modules just fine, even in the absence of the Flutter plugin. Having the Flutter plugin installed would give you additional capabilities, above and beyond just static analysis, refactorings, ... available from the Dart plugin.

comment_data.body:
Sounds good in principle. For Bazel, we don't use the Flutter module type at all.

Do we gain anything from it in pub-based projects? (Seems like we just need to cache what we learned from pubspec.yaml?)
Early on we had some conversations about [facets](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/2016.2/facet.html), which on the surface look promising.  Curious what @alexander-doroshko thinks?
There are no facets in Small IDEs.
Ah!  Well that explains why we didn't push harder. Any thoughts on @devoncarew's question?

@`[Dart support enabled for the module] === [The module has an order entry pointing to a 'Dart SDK' project-level library that in its turn contains valid Dart SDK roots]`.

So one option is to try to extend this rule:
`[Flutter support enabled for a module] === [Dart support enabled + referenced Dart SDK is the one inside a Flutter SDK]`. An obvious downside is that it will be impossible to disable flutterness for a regular Dart project without downloading a separate standalone Dart SDK. Also it will be impossible to have both Flutter and Dart modules within one IntelliJ IDEA project.

Another thought is Module's setOption/getOptionValue. Module options are serialized in IMLs. I didn't play much with them.

Other ways to detect that the given Dart module is also a Flutter one could be considered as well.

> Also it will be impossible to have both Flutter and Dart modules within one IntelliJ IDEA project.

I don't understand this one. If the two modules had different values for their Dart SDK, one pointed to a non-flutter dart and one to a flutter dart sdk, wouldn't re recognize the first module as a Dart one, and the 2nd as a Dart+Flutter one?
As I understand it, Dart SDK's will soon be per-project, not per-module. We aren't planning to switch this to per-module, are we?

Ideally the user shouldn't have to do anything and we should autodetect this without having a Flutter module type. We could still detect this per-module, but the module type can go away entirely.

For pub packages, I see there is a flutter constraint [1] but I don't know if it's required.

Are there other non-IDEA files we can look at? I suppose we could look at lib/main.dart to detect this.

[1] https://www.dartlang.org/tools/pub/pubspec#flutter-sdk-constraints

> Dart SDK's will soon be per-project, not per-module

Yes, that's the answer, thanks!
will soon be -> already for a long time in 2017.1 EAP :)

> Ideally the user shouldn't have to do anything and we should autodetect this

ðŸ‘

The current plan here is to follow @alexander-doroshko's advice above (March 13th) and have a Flutter module be determined by the following:

`[Flutter support enabled for a module] === [Dart support enabled + referenced Dart SDK is the one inside a Flutter SDK]`.

Start of work is here: https://github.com/jwren/flutter-intellij/tree/rm-module-type

How do you rate the downsides? Especially the 2nd one that has no workaround.

>An obvious downside is that it will be impossible to disable flutterness for a regular Dart project without downloading a separate standalone Dart SDK. Also, it will be impossible to have both Flutter and Dart modules within one IntelliJ IDEA project.
It seems like checking the pubspec file for a flutter dependency would be pretty reasonable?
Resolved in master branch now with https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/pull/1213

rename.from: (re-)consider how we define flutterness for a module
rename.to: re-consider how we define flutterness for a module

title: re-consider how we define flutterness for a module
